entity_name: J. C. King, Chief, Western Hemisphere Division
summary: J. C. King was the Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division. The documents indicate his involvement in overseeing Cuban operations, as evidenced by a report summarizing activities from September 1-15, 1961. He was also involved in planning to exploit Khrushchev's visit to Cuba in 1960, including instigating a church rally and spreading rumors of an assassination attempt. The documents also suggest his division was involved in gathering political intelligence, as seen in the memorandum detailing a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico. The documents span from 1960 to 1961, indicating his active role during this period.
key_connections: Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico
significance: J. C. King's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division, which was deeply involved in covert operations related to Cuba. These operations, including those aimed at destabilizing the Cuban government and exploiting political situations, are relevant to understanding the broader context of US-Cuban relations and potential motivations for individuals or groups involved in the JFK assassination. His division's activities and connections to key figures in Cuba and Mexico highlight the complex political landscape of the time.
